extreme waves that appear from nowhere on the nature of rogue waves
modulation instability akhmediev breathers and continuous wave supercontinuum generation
modulation instability akhmediev breathers and continuous wave supercontinuum generation

ANDS-Grants.description: Exploding solitons have been predicted in our works and their existence confirmed in experiments. Explosions occur regularly in variety of systems with continuous supply and dissipation of energy. Exploding solitons are more common than ordinary dissipative solitons. They occupy large areas in the parameter space and they can be generated relatively easily. Despite this fact, the phenomenon is highly complex and requires significant research efforts to understand. If such understanding is reached, the exploding solitons can be used for generation of pulses with wide spectral output similar to ``supercontinuum" radiation. Research in this direction will provide the basis for building powerful laser sources with wide spectral output.
ANDS-Grants.title: Discovery Projects - Grant ID: DP150102057

ANDS-Grants.description: Rapid progress in rogue wave research internationally requires the further development of an accurate theory of extreme waves in deep water and in optical fibers. Such progress is a necessity for our ability to predict their appearance in the ocean or their use in optics. This project will enhance the modelling of extreme waves by taking into account higher order effects such as third order dispersion, self-steepening and time delayed response, as well as dissipative and higher order nonlinear terms. These are essential for a precise description of both giant waves in the ocean and strong pulses in optics.
ANDS-Grants.title: Discovery Projects - Grant ID: DP140100265
